  \cellcolor{green!27}\small Nancy golf4life there is no truth in this 'test.' Kids use the color system to base negative and positive feelings. Adults do it as well.   \cellcolor{green!5}\small While the results of this study are indeed disturbing, it's important to keep in mind that it is not without flaws.¬† First, \textbf{black} has traditionally been associated with evil in most societies, while white is associated with goodness and purity.¬† (Even the Bible uses darkness as a symbol of evil and light as a symbol for good.)¬† This association is not so much \textbf{race} based as it is of color psychology and the values that different cultures have assigned to colors.¬† Likewise, dark colors are traditionally associated with negative feelings, especially sadness, while light colors are associated with positive feelings like happiness or excitement.¬† It is easy to see why someone who doesn't know better may, at first sight, assume that \textbf{black} people are bad and white people are good based on these color associations.¬† Second, the researchers seemed to make the kids choose one doll¬†or the other for each category.¬† If they had been given a choice for whether to answer the questions and had been allowed they had no preference, the results may have been much different.¬† I, for one, did not consider either doll to be especially pretty or ugly, good or bad (and FTR, I am white.)¬† If anything, it is more \textbf{racist} to make kids choose a "good" or "bad" doll simply based on the doll's \textbf{race}, since there is really no other visible measure of difference between the two of them.Does¬†experiment outcomes like this¬†demonstrate internalized \textbf{racism}?¬† Possibly.¬† But it could be for a million other reasons as well.¬† Let's not jump to conclusions until more detailed research can be done.\normalsize   & \cellcolor{green!5}Black, Race, Racism, Racist & \cellcolor{green!5}Ethnicity - Black, Ethnicity - General & \cellcolor{green!5}6/270 & \cellcolor{green!5}2.222 \\  \hline
